articles.headline: Why the Election Has Wall Street Frozen
articles.snippet: Among deal makers with fortunes at stake, the consequences of a Harris or a Trump win are increasingly murky.
articles.abstract: Among deal makers with fortunes at stake, the consequences of a Harris or a Trump win are increasingly murky.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the bankers and lawyers for Capital One and Discover were locked in tense negotiations in February over the timing for the merger of their companies, political factors loomed.

articles.headline: Boeing and Workers Dig In for a Long Fight, Despite Strike’s Cost
articles.snippet: Nearly a month into a union walkout, the aerospace giant withdrew its latest contract offer, and the two sides exchanged blame over the breakdown.
articles.abstract: Nearly a month into a union walkout, the aerospace giant withdrew its latest contract offer, and the two sides exchanged blame over the breakdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing and its largest union appear to be digging in for a long fight — even as some striking workers start to look for temporary jobs and the company risks having its credit rating downgraded to junk status.

articles.headline: Google Triumphs on the Nobel Stage as Tough Antitrust Fight Looms
articles.snippet: Two of the company’s A.I. researchers shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, just hours after the Justice Department started spelling out plans that could lead to its break up.
articles.abstract: Two of the company’s A.I. researchers shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, just hours after the Justice Department started spelling out plans that could lead to its break up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google, thanks to the tens of billions of dollars it makes every year from its online search business, has long pursued giant research projects that could one day change the world.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Steve Lohr and David McCabe

articles.headline: The Endless Downfall of a Crypto Power Couple
articles.snippet: Ryan Salame, an FTX executive, and Michelle Bond, a crypto policy advocate, were once a Washington power couple. Now they both face prison time.
articles.abstract: Ryan Salame, an FTX executive, and Michelle Bond, a crypto policy advocate, were once a Washington power couple. Now they both face prison time.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was a wealthy cryptocurrency executive with a shiny white Porsche and a luxury condo in the Bahamas. She was a crypto policy expert with political ambitions, advocating for the industry in Washington.

articles.headline: Amazon Could Be Forced to Treat Drivers as Employees
articles.snippet: Amazon’s delivery system depends on third-party companies. But labor regulators have challenged that model, possibly opening the way for unionization.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s delivery system depends on third-party companies. But labor regulators have challenged that model, possibly opening the way for unionization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vans marked with Amazon’s arrow logo have become ubiquitous on residential streets, a symbol of the nearly instantaneous delivery that has transformed online shopping.

articles.headline: Trump Spreads His Politics of Grievance to Nonwhite Voters
articles.snippet: Eight years ago, he won over many white voters, who were often called the forgotten Americans. Now, he hopes to make inroads with Black and Latino voters by stoking resentments and pointing to scapegoats.
articles.abstract: Eight years ago, he won over many white voters, who were often called the forgotten Americans. Now, he hopes to make inroads with Black and Latino voters by stoking resentments and pointing to scapegoats.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, former President Donald J. Trump fueled his political rise with dark appeals to white Christian voters, warning of immigrants coming for their jobs and nefarious efforts to undermine what he describes as the country’s true heritage.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Michael Gold

articles.headline: Republicans Appear Poised to Take Control of Senate, New Poll Shows
articles.snippet: The latest polling from The New York Times and Siena College shows Republicans leading in key Senate races in Montana, Texas and Florida.
articles.abstract: The latest polling from The New York Times and Siena College shows Republicans leading in key Senate races in Montana, Texas and Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: Control of the Senate appears likely to flip from the Democratic Party to the Republican Party this fall, as one of the nation’s most endangered Democrats, Senator Jon Tester of Montana, trails his Republican challenger in his bid for re-election, according to a new poll from The New York Times and Siena College.

articles.headline: Consumer Price Increases Cooled, but Not as Much as Expected
articles.snippet: The Consumer Price Index is moderating, but September’s report contained both good and bad news for policymakers.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Price Index is moderating, but September’s report contained both good and bad news for policymakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Price increases slowed in September, but the cool-down was less than economists had expected, in the latest reminder that bringing inflation back under control remained a somewhat bumpy process.

articles.headline: Airstrikes in Beirut Kill at Least 22 and Level a Building, Lebanese Officials Say
articles.snippet: Israel was behind the attack, Lebanon said, and it came on the same day that the U.N. said Israeli forces had fired on its peacekeepers, an episode that drew international condemnation.
articles.abstract: Israel was behind the attack, Lebanon said, and it came on the same day that the U.N. said Israeli forces had fired on its peacekeepers, an episode that drew international condemnation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes hit two buildings in a densely populated area of central Beirut on Thursday, Lebanon said, in what appeared to be the deadliest attack in the Lebanese capital in more than a year of fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.
articles.byline: By Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Aric Toler and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Ethel Kennedy, Passionate Supporter of the Family Legacy, Dies at 96
articles.snippet: She never remarried after the assassination of her husband, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and she devoted herself to working on behalf of the causes he had championed.
articles.abstract: She never remarried after the assassination of her husband, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and she devoted herself to working on behalf of the causes he had championed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and a popular and vital force in the Kennedy political dynasty, died on Thursday. She was 96.
